In the conventional case without VDF, the heat-dissipation rate  $q_{\rm ss}$ becomes proportional to the total entropy production rate $s_{\rm ss}$ in a steady state through the Clausius relation ($ s_{\rm ss}=q_{\rm ss}/T$). Then, the thermodynamic second law enforces the inequality $q_{\rm ss}\ge 0$ with the equality (NHD) holding only when the system is in EQ~\cite{Sekimoto,Harada2005,Harada2006}. This is why $q_{\rm ss}$ has been regarded as a fundamental quantity in the study of NEQ steady states, representing irreversibility. In fact, it can be shown that the FDT, the DB, and the NHD conditions are equivalent to each other~\cite{Sekimoto,Harada2005,Harada2006,Hatano2001,Speck2005,Crooks1998,Kurchan1998,Oono1998}. \end{matrix}

Regarding the FDT, we have checked that the response function matrix still remains in the same form of Eq.~(\ref{Rem}) while the correlation function matrix does not maintain the structure of Eq.~(\ref{Cem})~\cite{hknc}, and thus the vanishing like Eq.~(\ref{fdtnoDB}) is impossible. Consequently, this case belongs to the region where only the NHD is satisfied.


Usually, the DB, the FDT, and the NHD ($q_{\rm ss}=0$) are, respectively, considered as the signature of EQ. This is supported in the conventional systems with no velocity-dependent force, as the three conditions simultaneously hold in EQ while none of them holds in NEQ. Our results, however, point out that such an identification of EQ/NEQ is not possible, in general, by demonstrating that the equivalence among the three conditions (FDT/DB/NHD) is broken in the presence of a velocity-dependent force. We propose a new relation among the three conditions and confirm it with a few example systems. The velocity-dependent force is a characteristics of the so-called ``active-matter systems'' of recent considerable attention, modeling a generic NEQ entity abundant in biological objects. We believe that the study of the FDT/DB/NHD in such systems will uncover the new physics behind them, and also provide a unified and concrete view on EQ and NEQ.
